{{EngvarB|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox women |title =Women in Myanmar |image =A_BURMESE_LADY.jpg |caption = A Burmese woman in traditional garb, c. 1920. |gii = 0.437 (2012) |gii_rank = 80th |ggg = NR (2012) |ggg_rank = NR |matdeath = 200 (2010) |womparl = 4.0% (2012) |femed = 18.0% (2010) |womlab = 75.0% (2011) }} {{Women in society sidebar}} Historically, '''women in Myanmar''' (also known as '''Burma''') have had a unique [[social status]] and esteemed women in [[Burma|Burmese society]]. According to the research done by [[Mya Sein]], Burmese [[women]] "for centuries – even before [[recorded history]]" owned a "high measure of independence" and had retained their "legal and economic rights" despite the influences of [[Buddhism]] and [[Hinduism]]. Burma once had a [[matriarchal]] system that includes the exclusive right to inherit [[oil well]]s and the right to inherit the position as [[village head]]. Burmese women were also appointed to high offices by [[Burmese kings]], can become chieftainesses and [[Supayalat|queens]].<ref name=Atlantic>Daw Mya Sein. [https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1958/02/the-women-of-burma/6822/ "Women in Burma"], The Atlantic, Atlantic Magazine, February 1958.</ref>
==Traditional dress== The ''htamein'' ({{lang|my|ထမီ}} {{IPA-my|tʰəmèɪɴ|}}) is one of the traditional dresses of Burmese women.<ref name=Atlantic/><ref name=Falconer/> This skirtcloth or lower body wrapper was worn by women during the [[Konbaung Dynasty]] (1752–1855) as a wrap-around skirt, or sometimes as a folded clothing material placed "tightly across the abdomen slightly left center of the waist".<ref name=Falconer/> In comparison, Burmese men wore the traditional lower garment known as the ''pahso'' ({{lang|my|ပုဆိုး}} {{IPA-my|pəsʰó|}}).<ref name=Falconer>Falconer, John and Luca Invernizzi Tettoni. [https://books.google.com/books?id=yQeGTsOoD0IC&pg=PA189&lpg=PA189&dq=htamein&source=bl&ots=LnZcuhWOQw&sig=iqzvujhwSIzR6qqNntT5qPFgueU&hl=en&ei=iYezTfj2E8jZgQem-9THCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEoQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false Burmese Design and Architecture], Tuttle Publishing, page 189.</ref>
==Love and marriage==
Marriages were previously allowed between Burmese women and male foreigners provided that the divisional courts in Burma were informed within 21 days of advance notice. However, in May 2010, the government of Burma disallowed conducting of marriage ceremonies between Burmese women and male foreigners.<ref name=Irrawaddy/> One of the suggested reasons was to avoid [[human trafficking]].<ref name=Irrawaddy>Thae Thae. [http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=18550 ''Burmese Women Not Allowed to Marry Foreigners''], The Irrawaddy, 25 May 2010.</ref> Burmese women became victims of human traffickers and were traded for the sex industry in Pakistan and Thailand.<ref name=Global>[http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/burma.htm Trafficking], Burma/Myanmar, Factbook on Global Sexual Exploitation, Coalition Against Trafficking in Women</ref>
To some extent, arranged marriages was also a part of Burmese tradition, however, the Burmese women have the right to refuse the offer of being betrothed to the parents' chosen partner for her. At present, young Burmese women can choose to marry someone for love.<ref name=Irrawaddy/>
==Women's rights== {{Main|Women's rights in Myanmar}}
[[File:Aung San Suu Kyi (December 2011).jpg|thumb|[[Aung San Suu Kyi]].]] In 2000, the Asian Women's Resource Exchange (AWORC) published a report entitled ''Human Rights in Burma'' from the ''Forum News'' (August 1998) describing that by tradition, Burmese women are maternal self-abnegators, meaning that these women "consistently forgo their own needs in order to give their children first priority." The report also indicated that rural and urban Burmese women were affected by the deteriorating economic climate in Burma.<ref name=Aworc>[http://www.aworc.org/bpfa/pub/sec_e/vio00001.html Human Rights in Burma], Asian Women's Resource Exchange (AWORC), 2000</ref>
As a result, Burmese families were "increasingly prioritising the rights of males over females to limited resources." These changes affected the access of Burmese women to nutrition, medical services, vocational training, and other educational opportunities. Burmese women became unwilling porters and unpaid labourers for the military, including becoming victims of slavery, murder, torture, rape, and attacks.<ref name=Aworc>[http://www.aworc.org/bpfa/pub/sec_e/vio00001.html Human Rights in Burma], Asian Women's Resource Exchange (AWORC), 2000</ref>
Historically, urban Burmese women "enjoyed high levels of social power" but later became confronted with restrictions on speech and limitations in acquiring high level positions in both private and public offices.<ref name=Aworc/> According to AWORC, only a few number of Burmese women receive education related to reproductive rights and safe birth control practices, thus making them prone to being infected by HIV and AIDS.<ref name=Aworc/>
In January 2008, BBC News featured Burmese [[Kayan Lahwi]] women who became tourist attractions in Thailand because of the tradition of wearing coils of brass around their necks. The rings of brass push the "women's shoulders and ribs down" throughout several years giving the effect as if the necks had been stretched, thus described as sporting "unnaturally long, [[giraffe]]-like necks."<ref name=BBC>Harding, Andrew. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7215182.stm Burmese women in Thai 'human zoo'], 30 January 2008.</ref>

Lutsenko's wife Iryna Lutsenko is a current member of the [[Ukrainian parliament]]. ==Early life== Lutsenko was born in [[Rivne]]. His father was Vitaliy Ivanovych Lutsenko (15 March 1937 – 4 June 1999), who was elected people's deputy of Ukraine in [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1994|1994]] and [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 1998|1998]], and secretary of the Central Committee of [[Communist Party of Ukraine]].{{Cite web|url=http://src-h.slav.hokudai.ac.jp/ukrregions/data/99.html|title=Lutsenko Vitaliy Ivanovich biography|publisher=[[Hokkaido University]]|language=Russian}} Lutsenko's mother is Vira Mikhailivna (born 1936), a [[Veterinary medicine|veterinarian]]. Lutsenko earned his degree in engineering in 1989 from [[Lviv Polytechnic|Lviv Polytechnical Institute]]. ==Political biography== Lutsenko gained public fame as one of the leaders of the [[Ukraine without Kuchma!]] campaign, which followed the [[Cassette Scandal]] of 2000.[http://edition.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/europe/03/05/ukraine.tent/index.html?iref=allsearch Ukrainians renew tent protest], [[CNN]] (5 March 2001) He was also one of the "faces of the [[Orange revolution]]". From 1991, Lutsenko was a long-term member of the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU); prior to his appointment to the executive branch, he was people's deputy in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (the Ukrainian parliament) beginning in February 2002. Lutsenko belonged to the so-called "right wing" of SPU, which takes a pro-European position akin to social democratic parties in the rest of Europe, rather than a post-Soviet conservative socialism. As a Minister, Lutsenko refused to run in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]] on his party list. However, he has run for both the [[Kyivrada|Kiev City Council]] and Rivne Oblast Council simultaneously in the lists of the Socialist Party – "to make the point", as he explained. Having won these seats, Lutsenko resigned from both in favor of his Minister's position as the [[Constitution of Ukraine]] prohibits occupying positions in the legislative and executive branches of the government at the same time. ===Resignation from the Socialist Party=== After his appointment as a minister, Lutsenko suspended his membership of the SPU in the summer of 2006 as a result of the party leader [[Oleksandr Moroz]]'s entering into a Parliamentary coalition with the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and the [[Party of Regions]] of the previous PM [[Yanukovych]]. When the Parliamentary coalition of the [[Party of Regions]], the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communists]], and the defected [[Socialist Party of Ukraine|Socialists]] began to take shape, Lutsenko stated flatly that he refused to continue serving as the minister in a future government formed by these parties. However, after President [[Viktor Yushchenko]] agreed to allow the forming of the cabinet in exchange for several [[concession (politics)|political concessions]] including the ability to pick the Minister of Interior, Lutsenko stated that the president asked him personally to remain as the minister, and he would do so. Lutsenko was formally dismissed by the [[Verkhovna Rada]] on 1 December 2006.{{Cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=411-16|title=On dismissal of Yuriy Lutsenko from position of Minister of Internal Affairs|date=1 December 2006|language=Ukrainian}} Lutsenko then (December 2006) created [[Civil Movement "People's Self-Defense"]].[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php/java/index.php?id=148&listid=38877 Yuriy Lutsenko's initiative to create civil movement "People's self-defense" supported by political party "Ukraine, onward!"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223135329/http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php/java/index.php?id=148&listid=38877 |date=23 February 2012 }}, [[Radio Ukraine]] (25 December 2006) 18 December 2007 Lutsenko again became minister of Internal Affairs, when [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] was again elected [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]]. ===Incident at Frankfurt Airport=== In early May 2009 Lutsenko became entangled in a scandal concerning his behaviour during a visit to Germany. According to [[Newspapers in Germany|German newspaper]] [[Bild]] Lutsenko was detained at [[Frankfurt Airport]] by the [[German police]] in a state of acute alcohol intoxication. The Ukrainian Interior Ministry dismissed these allegations. According to the information of the Ministry, on 4 May 2009 the Interior Ministry's delegation was detained at the Frankfurt airport during document checks, and missed the flight. The flight crew refused to take them on board. The delegation decided to catch the next flight. "There were no handcuffs, no drunken conflict," the department said. On 12 May 2009 Yuri Lutsenko sent in his resignation from the post of interior minister. In his [[letter of resignation]] the Minister described the incident that happened in [[Frankfurt]], and stressed that the German police had officially apologized to the Ukrainian delegation for this incident; but that despite this, German mass media disseminated false publications, which were later re-published by Ukrainian media. He said none of these publications mentioned the apologies of the German police. Lutsenko was confident that a dirty campaign had been waged against him in Ukraine. The aim of the campaign, according to him, was to destabilize the work of the Interior Ministry.[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-315132.html Lutsenko sent in his resignation from post of Interior Minister], [[UNIAN]] (12 May 2009) The [[Ukrainian Parliament]] has to agree with the resignation of a Minister before the Minister can leave her/his post. On 15 May 2009 it passed a resolution, stipulating to address the government with a request to suspend Yuri Lutsenko from the post of the Interior Minister of Ukraine until the "drunken incident" is investigated.[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-315779.html Verkhovna Rada asks government to suspend Lutsenko from post], [[UNIAN]] (15 May 2009) From 12 May 2009 till 14 May 2009 and again on 15 May 2009 faction members of the [[Opposition (parliamentary)|oppositional]] [[Party of Regions]] blocked the [[Ukrainian parliament]]'s rostrum and presidium demanding the resignation of Lutsenko. this will not influence the term of Lutsenko's imprisonment.[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/higher-court-to-announce-ruling-on-lutsenkos-second-cassation-on-april-10-2/ Higher court to announce ruling on Lutsenko’s second cassation on April 10], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (5 April 2013) ====Pardoning==== After already having suggested it earlier [[Ukrainian President|President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on 5 April 2013 proposed the presidential commission on pardons urgently to consider the request by Verkhovna Rada Human Rights Commissioner [[Valeriya Lutkovska]] to pardon Lutsenko.[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/yanukovych-proposes-presidential-commission-urgently-consider-pardoning-lutsenko-and-filipchuk/ Yanukovych proposes presidential commission urgently consider pardoning Lutsenko and Filipchuk], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (6 April 2013) The requests to pardon Lutsenko was made by Ukrainian parliamentary Lutkovska, former [[President of the European Parliament]] [[Pat Cox]] and former [[Polish President]] [[Aleksander Kwasniewski]]. Lutkovska asked to pardon Lutsenko "due to the European standards of human rights, which include providing effective medical care to persons detained in prisons".{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/04/5/6987544/ ЯНУКОВИЧ НАКАЗАВ НЕГАЙНО РОЗІБРАТИСЯ З ПОМИЛУВАННЯМ ЛУЦЕНКА ''Yanukovych ordered IMMEDIATELY deal with pardons Lutsenko''], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (5 April 2013) On 7 April 2013 a decree by Yanukovych pardoned Lutsenko (among others) for health reasons and "to decriminalize and humanize Ukrainian legislation"[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/yanukovych-human-rights-policies-are-oriented-towards-european-standards-pardons-commission-2/ Yanukovych human rights policies are oriented towards European standards – pardons commission], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 April 2013) and the same day he was released from prison. The decree also exempted from further punishment Lutsenko's fellow Minister in the [[second Tymoshenko Government]] [[Heorhiy Filipchuk]]. Lutsenko stated the day after his release he will "continue to remain in politics".[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/lutsenko-says-has-no-presidential-ambitions-3/ Lutsenko says has no presidential ambitions], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 April 2013) Lutsenko and his family had repeatedly stated that they would not seek a pardon, because they believe the charges where groundless and political punishment.[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/lutsenkos-wife-pleasantly-shocked-at-ombudspersons-request-to-pardon-ex-minister/ Lutsenko’s wife pleasantly shocked at ombudsperson’s request to pardon ex-minister], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (6 April 2013) Nevertheless, Lutsenko's wife [[Iryna Lutsenko]] welcomed the request. On 8 April 2013 the [[European Union]] welcomed the pardoning of Lutsenko and Filipchuk and urged Ukraine to continue addressing "the cases of selective justice".[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/ashton-fule-salute-lutsenkos-pardon-waiting-for-kyiv-to-deal-with-selective-justice/ Ashton, Fule salute Lutsenko’s pardon, waiting for Kyiv to deal with selective justice], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (8 April 2013) ===Political career after April 2013 pardoning=== In the spring of 2013 Lutsenko established the non-parliamentary movement "Third Republic".[http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/lutsenkos_third_republic_will_not_be_west_ukraine_movement___political_scientist_302387 Lutsenko's Third Republic will not be West Ukraine movement - political scientist], [[Ukrinform]] (24 April 2013)
[http://www.dw.de/lutsenko-ukraine-needs-the-eu-association-deal/a-16773485 Lutsenko: Ukraine needs the EU association deal], [[Deutsche Welle]] (26 April 2013)
[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/lutsenko-presents-third-republic-public-movement-in-lviv/ Lutsenko presents Third Republic public movement in Lviv], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (17 June 2013) At the time he was not member of a political party because he is "on a path to the same goal pursued by [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|"Fatherland"]] from the bottom up and from the people, by organizing a connection between opposition parties and the populace".[http://ukrainianweek.com/Politics/83457 United Twice], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (2 July 2013) In November 2013 Lutsenko became one of the organizers of [[Euromaidan]].[http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/opposition-leader-yuri-lutsenko-injured-in-clashes-in-ukrainian-capital-1.1634667 Opposition leader Yuri Lutsenko injured in clashes in Ukrainian capital], [[CTV News]] (11 January 2014)[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/euromaidan-movement-to-move-off-streets-regroup-332614.html EuroMaidan movement to move off streets, regroup], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 November 2013) Lutsenko was hospitalised on 11 January 2014 in an intensive care ward after being beaten by police in protests following the sentence of verdicts in an [[alleged 2011 Lenin statue bomb plot in Boryspil]].[http://www.euronews.com/2014/01/11/dozens-hurt-as-fresh-clashes-erupt-in-ukraine/ Dozens hurt as fresh clashes erupt in Ukraine], [[Euronews]] (11 January 2014) Lutsenko had arrived at the courthouse after initial clashes between police and protesters an after 400 riot police had arrived.[http://www.latimes.com/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-ukraine-opposition-leader-20140111,0,3338928.story#axzz2q2LeQTMX Ukraine opposition leader injured in clash with police], [[Los Angeles Times]] (11 January 2014) After the convicts had been transported away, several cars followed the riot police bus and blocked it at Peremohy avenue, near Svyatoshino police station. A crowd soon gathered, demanding from policemen to open their faces and to show their IDs. According to Lutsenko's wife Iryna her husband had been attacked by police as he tried to break up the violence.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-25692076 Ukraine ex-minister Lutsenko hurt in clashes in Kiev], [[BBC News]] (11 January 2014) Lutsenko has received an official status of victim of a crime.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/185608.html Lutsenko given victim status after 2-hour interrogation by investigator, says wife], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (13 January 2014) On 17 June 2014 Lutsenko was appointed as (non-staff) adviser to President [[Petro Poroshenko]]; he had also been adviser to Poroshenko's predecessor acting President [[Oleksandr Turchynov]].[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/209626.html Former interior minister Lutsenko appointed as non-staff adviser to Ukrainian president], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (17 June 2014) Lutsenko's old party [[People's Self-Defense Political Party]] was renamed [[Third Ukrainian Republic (party)|Third Ukrainian Republic]] in July 2014; however, Lutsenko was not a member of this revamped People's Self-Defense Political Party.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/07/1/7030605 For Lutsenko registered party], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (1 July 2014)
{{uk icon}} [http://tvi.ua/new/2014/07/01/tretya_ukrayinska_respublika_lucenka_stala_partiyeyu Ministry of Justice registered political party "Third Ukrainian Republic." ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707033554/http://tvi.ua/new/2014/07/01/tretya_ukrayinska_respublika_lucenka_stala_partiyeyu |date=7 July 2014 }}, [[TVi (channel)]] (1 July 2014) On 27 August 2014 Lutsenko was elected the leader of the [[Bloc of Petro Poroshenko]] party. In the [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] Lutsenko was re-elected into parliament after being in the top 10 of the electoral list of Petro Poroshenko Bloc.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233747.html General official results of Rada election], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (11 November 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/233696.html Central Election Commission announces official results of Rada election on party tickets], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (11 November 2014)[http://www.sputniknews.com/politics/20141025/194556662/Petro-Poroshenko-Bloc-Facts-and-Details.html Petro Poroshenko Bloc: Facts and Details], [[Sputnik News]] (25.10.2014) He then became Parliamentary leader of the parties faction in parliament.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/236632.html Bloc of Petro Poroshenko faction headed by Yuriy Lutsenko formed in parliament], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (27 November 2014) On 28 August 2015 the [[UDAR]] party merged into Petro Poroshenko Bloc.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/286616.html Klitschko becomes leader of Petro Poroshenko Bloc 'Solidarity' party], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (28 August 2015) UDAR party leader [[Vitali Klitschko]] at the same party congress replaced Lutsenko as new party leader. ==Prosecutor General of Ukraine== On 12 May 2016 parliament appointed Lutsenko [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine]]. This after it had changed amendments to legislation allowing a person to hold the office without a law degree. Lutsenko (who has no law degreehttps://web.archive.org/web/20160422150934/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-21/where-s-ukraine-headed-watch-who-gets-the-top-prosecutor-s-job) was also stripped of his MP mandate. After Ukrainian politician and activist [[Kateryna Handziuk]] died from complications from an acid attack on 4 November 2018 human rights organisations and NGOs demand the resignation of Lutsenko and Interior Minister [[Arsen Avakov]]. "To prove that no one clings to power" Lutsenko announced his intention to resign (as Prosecutor General) on 6 November 2018. He also noted he considered the investigation of the case effective and that he was outraged by what he considered "PR on blood" around the Handziuk case.[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10326951-ukrainian-chief-prosecutor-lutsenko-decides-to-resign.html Ukrainian Chief Prosecutor Lutsenko decides to resign], [[UNIAN]] (6 November 2018)
[https://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/543099.html I am submitting my resignation today — Prosecutor General Lutsenko], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (6 November 2018) On 9 November 2018 President [[Petro Poroshenko]] refused to approve Lutsenko's resignation.[https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10332042-poroshenko-turns-down-prosecutor-general-s-resignation-letter.html Poroshenko turns down prosecutor general's resignation letter], [[UNIAN]] (9 November 2018) ==Personal life== Lutsenko's wife Iryna Lutsenko was elected into parliament [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|in the October 2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] on the party list of [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|"Fatherland"]] (number 18).{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2012/11/11/6977259/ Список депутатів нової Верховної Ради], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (11 November 2012)
